div1.p: Byam writes that the additional material on Finlay will be included in Carter's article. He discusses Finlay's role in the yellow fever work.

5th June 1919.
THE PRACTICE OF MEDICINE IN THE TROPICS.
Dear General Carter,
div1.p:
We shall be delighted to include
the additional matter you sent to-day, as it is very
right that Finlay should get the credit due to him.
As you say, most people in this country have a very
wrong idea as to the order of events. I would pre-
fer, however, to include what you have written in
the body of your article, as we are anxious to avoid
foot notes whenever possible. The type will be the
same for all matter, as we feel that if information
is worthy of inclusion, it should be presented in a
form that will ensure its being read.

As you know, proofs of your
article will be sent to you, when it will be possible
for you to make such alterations as you may wish,
though I would ask you not to alter the order of the
sections, as we are anxious that information should
be arranged in the same way for all diseases. This,
of course, being for the convenience of readers.

By now, no doubt, you will have
received my letter of May 13th, so that I shall look
forward to hearing from you again in the near future.

As you requested, a cheque for £11. 11. 0.,
has been paid on your behalf to the “Officers'
Families Fund”, from whom you should receive due
acknowledgment.
